section-block.rac_essential-question: How can we express ourselves through music and dance?

section-block.rac_book_title_byline: Based on a Bob Marley song, adapted by Cedella Marley, illustrated by Vanessa Brantley-Newton
section-block.rac_book_summary: This book features the lyrics to the classic Bob Marley song “Three Little Birds.” The three little birds in the book help remind the boy and his family not to worry because “every little thing is gonna be alright.”

section-block.rac_top-left_header: Let’s Create | WEEK 2: Sing and Dance

section-block.rac_body-text: Review shapes by showing examples of shapes they learned (many are found in Pattern Blocks) and asking children to name each shape and say its properties.
Work together as a class to find circles, triangles, squares, and rectangles around the room. As you spot one, have children describe what makes it that shape.

section.rac_teacher-talk_blue: We are going to read Every Little Thing by Bob Marley and Cedella Marley and illustrated by Vanessa Brantley-Newton.
You know that Lala loves all sorts of books. This book is special because it is also a song.
There is a question I want you to think about as we read. We will talk about it after we read.
section.rac_guiding-question_blue: How do the people in the story feel?

section.rac_body-text: This book is based on a song by Bob Marley. If you know the song, teach children the chorus.
Focus on Shapes: Pause and ask children to identify different shapes they see on the page.
section.rac_teacher-talk_blue: What are the birds doing? What is the cat doing? Cats chase birds.
The boy is worried about the rain.
What are the birds doing? How do you feel when you hear music?

The birds sing not to worry. What does it mean when someone says everything will be all right? How does the boy feel now? Do you think hearing that every little thing will be all right would help you if you were worried?
Does this boy seem happy or sad? Do you see any shapes in the swing set? Where are they?
What are the children doing? Do you think they are happy? Can you find any circles in this picture? (MB)
How does the boy feel after hearing the birds’ song again? Can you find any squares in this picture?
Let’s talk about the guiding question: How do the people in the story feel?
section.rac_body-text: Use Equity Sticks to call on children to answer the question.
Possible responses:
section.rac_body-text_bulleted: The boy is worried about the rain.
The boy is happy to play.
The boy is sad he is left out.

section.rac_body-text: Write and read aloud short sentences about feelings as children watch.

rac_support_challenge-box.rac_teacher-talk_blue: How does the boy on the swing feel when he is alone?
The boy on the swing feels s___ (sad).
The boy on the swing feels sad.
How do people in the story change the way they feel?

section-block.rac_child_development_hed-green: Child Development: Naming and Describing Shapes
section-block.rac_child_development_body: Giving children the proper mathematic vocabulary lays essential groundwork for their longterm understanding of math. Teaching children the names of shapes and helping them become comfortable identifying both the names and the qualities of shapes is key in preparing them for more advanced geometry.

section-block.rac_top-left_header: Let’s Create | WEEK 2: Sing and Dance

section-block.rac_column_heds_no_paragraph_rule_day_2: Share the Mind Builder: Play With Others

rac_body-text.rac_teacher-talk_blue: Inviting someone to play with you is a way of being nice to that person. Asking a friend or classmate to play lets them know that you want them to join you. When you join others, you can add to their games and make it more fun. How do you feel when someone invites you to play?

section.rac_teacher-talk_blue: Today we will revisit the book Every Little Thing by Bob Marley and Cedella Marley and illustrated by Vanessa Brantley-Newton. We will look for times when children are playing together.
Clifford loves reading books with his friends! He invites you to read this book with him and look for places in the story where people invite others to play.

section.rac_column_heds_with_rule: Close-Read: Connect to the Mind Builder
section.rac_body-text: Focus on Shapes: Pause to help children notice shapes throughout the book.
section.rac_teacher-talk_blue: The children are playing with a ball. The ball looks like a circle, but it is a shape called a sphere.
How does the boy on the swing feel? How do you know?
What happens now? How does the boy invite the other boy to play? (MB)
How does the boy feel after being invited to play with the other children? How do they feel playing with him? (MB)
What shape can you find on the milk? Can you find any other shapes?
The moon is out the window. The moon is also a sphere! What else is a sphere?
The birds and cat and boy are all singing together. Why do you think they all decided to sing together? (MB)

section.rac_body-text: Teach children how to invite classmates to join them in play. Have children practice the dialogue with someone sitting near them, and then ask a few children to model the dialogue in front of the group.
Give children extra center time, but require them to ask at least two classmates to play.
Have children share how they felt being invited and playing together.
Transcribe children’s speech as they describe inviting friends and classmates to play.

section-block.rac_child_development_body: Showing respect by inviting someone you don’t know to join you is an essential lifelong skill. Support children’s ability to initiate play and join in groups already playing by looking for teachable moments when children are at play. Helping children develop the ability to make friends is a gift that can last a lifetime! (Encourageplay.com/Play and Social Skills)

section-block.rac_top-left_header: Let’s Create | WEEK 2: Sing and Dance

section-block.rac_body-text: Review making patterns. Show ABAB and AABB patterns using two colors of Connecting Cubes. Remind children that words and sounds can also make patterns.
Explain that rhymes are two words that sound the same. Sometimes there is a pattern in the rhymes. Sing “Mary Had a Little Lamb,” putting extra emphasis on rhymes.

section.rac_teacher-talk_blue: Today we are rereading Every Little Thing by Bob Marley and Cedella Marley and illustrated by Vanessa Brantley-Newton.
Lala loves this book because the words make her feel like dancing!
Music can change how we feel. As we read today, think about this question:
section.rac_guiding-question_blue: How does the music change how the people in the book feel?

section.rac_body-text: Ask children to listen for patterns within the words of the book.
section.rac_teacher-talk_blue: Do you hear any rhyming words? How do you know they rhyme? Let’s listen for other words that rhyme and look for patterns.
The house is a square in the front. Do you think it’s cube? What would make it a cube?
What is the boy doing in the rain? Is he happy or sad it is raining? How does the song in the book make the boy feel better?
The children are playing with the boy on the swing and are happy. How does the music help them play together? (MB)
What mistake did the boy make? How can he fix his mistake? Is he worried?
The birds are humming soft rhymes. Are there any rhymes in the words? Let’s listen again.
Let’s go through the book and see if we can find a pattern of other rhyming words!
Did you listen and remember as we read the story today? How does the music change how the people in the book feel?
section.rac_body-text: Guide children to Turn and Talk. Use Equity Sticks to ask children to share their responses.
Possible responses:
section.rac_body-text_bulleted: The music makes the boy dance in the rain.
The music helps the boy sleep.

section.rac_body-text: Share a pen with children as you draw and write together about how music affects how they feel.

rac_support_challenge-box.rac_teacher-talk_blue: How does the boy feel about the rain after hearing the song?
The music helps the boy feel h___ (happy).
The music helps the boy feel happy.
How can you share your feelings with music?

section-block.rac_child_development_body: Some children may be sensitive about making mistakes and possible repercussions. Reinforce that mistakes can happen and that you are there to help. Guide children to notice that when the boy in the book makes a mistake, the adults do not scold him. We can all learn and grow from our mistakes.

section-block.rac_top-left_header: Let’s Create | WEEK 2: Sing and Dance

section-block.rac_body-text: Play a pattern game. Start with an ABAB pattern like circle, square, circle, square. Then add hand gestures for children to make as they say each shape in the pattern.
Sing a familiar song like “Twinkle, Twinkle, Little Star,” noting the rhyming words (star/are and high/sky). Then sing a different song the children know, asking them to point out the rhyme.

section.rac_column_heds_no_paragraph_rule: Share the Big Chart of Big Ideas
section.rac_teacher-talk_blue: This week we are going to sing Old MacDonald’s Farm.
Every Little Thing and Old MacDonald’s Farm both teach through song. Let’s look for more connections as we read!
section.rac_hilight_teacher_inst_new: Show the Every Little Thing book cover.

section.rac_teacher-talk_blue: As we read, let’s think about this week’s concept question:
How can we express ourselves through music and dance?

section.rac_column_heds_with_rule: Close-Read: Connect to the Big Idea
section.rac_body-text: Read aloud the Teacher Text on the Big Chart, stopping to ask questions.
section.rac_teacher-talk_blue: Animals share with noises. We can share with song. As we read, let’s see how the animals express themselves. Let’s practice the different sounds animals on Old MacDonald’s farm make.
section.rac_body-text: Before beginning to sing, point to each animal to review its name and the sound it makes.
section.rac_teacher-talk_blue: The song goes E-I-E-I-O, and again, E-I-E-I-O. If another E came after that, what would come next? How do you know?
We’ve sung about cows and chickens. I am noticing a pattern in this song. What do you notice?
The next animal in the song is a goat. How did we do? Were we right about the pattern?
Songs are a type of pattern, because they repeat some words or sounds over and over in the same order.

section.rac_body-text: Provide arts and crafts supplies, and demonstrate how to make an animal mask. Encourage children to make any animal they would like, even if it isn’t a traditional farm animal.
After they finish, help children put on their masks and sit in a circle. Sing Old McDonald again, having each child say what sound their animal makes.
Provide a writing prompt about music and give feedback as children draw and write in response to the prompt.

section-block.rac_child_development_body: Children might combine English and their home language into a single sentence. This happens because they are learning two or more languages at the same time, and might only know certain words in one language. However, young bilingual learners tend to learn words at the same rate as children who only speak one language.

section-block.rac_top-left_header: Let’s Create | WEEK 2: Sing and Dance

section-block.rac_body-text: Teach children dance steps, or a repeating set of motions, to a song. This helps children develop gross motor skills while having fun!
Tell children that in addition to song, dance can also be a way to express yourself. Sing “If You’re Happy and You Know It” and have children clap, stomp, and flap to show happiness.
Get children excited for this lesson by conducting a “shape count.” Work together to count the number of circles they can find in the classroom. Repeat with squares.

section.rac_teacher-talk_blue: Let’s reread Every Little Thing by Bob Marley and Cedella Marley and illustrated by Vanessa Brantley-Newton once more.
Lala likes this story because she likes to express himself through music!
We saw how different people and animals express themselves. When we read today, think about this question:
section.rac_guiding-question_blue: What part of the song in the book reminds you of your life?

section.rac_teacher-talk_blue: Let’s reread the book one more time. This time, we will act like the animals and people in the book. We will also talk about shapes.
The boy is happy, so he does a dance in the puddles. Let’s all do our own happy dances in our spots! Do you ever dance in puddles?
Now the whole group plays with the ball because they are happy. The ball in the picture is a circle, but a real ball is a sphere. Let’s throw a pretend sphere around.
The birds sing to cheer up the boy after he makes a mistake. Let’s all sing to say we want our friends to be happy. We can sing part of “If You’re Happy and You Know It.”
It looks like it’s the boy’s bedtime and his mom is singing to help the boy sleep. Let’s all sing quietly to pretend to help someone sleep. Would that help you sleep?
The birds are singing and flying around to invite the cat to play with them. They get along, even though cats and birds normally don’t. Will you please all sing and dance with me?
section.rac_body-text: Sing the song chorus or another song from class.

section.rac_teacher-talk_blue: Let’s talk about the guiding question: What part of the song in the book reminds you of your life?
section.rac_body-text: Ask children to Turn and Talk. Use Equity Sticks to choose several children to share their responses.
Possible responses:
section.rac_body-text_bulleted: I invite a sad friend to play.
My mom and dad sing to make me feel happy.
I sometimes cry when I am sad.

section.rac_body-text: Invite children to write or draw about a time that music made them feel happy.

rac_support_challenge-box.rac_teacher-talk_blue: What could you do if a friend looks sad or lonely?
I can invite my friend to pl______ (play) with me.
I can invite my friend to play with me.
How can asking someone to play help a new classmate feel welcomed?

section-block.rac_child_development_hed-green: Child Development: Finding Shapes All Around Us
section-block.rac_child_development_body: You can help children understand geometry by encouraging them to notice the geometric shapes all around them. By pointing out shapes both in images in the book and in the real world, you help them become more familiar with shapes and more enthusiastic about learning geometry.
